metadata.sermon_title: TRINITY SUNDAY 1993: The Multicultural Good News
metadata.sermon_start_end: A few days ago, as I was beginning to think about this sermon for Trinity Sunday, I heard an agnostic friend refer to the activity of the Christian church as “proselytizing.” [...] In him there is news so good that we cannot possibly keep it to ourselves, for he has gone before us with the Great Commission to all the peoples of the earth, and lo, Jesus is with us always, even to the end of the world. Amen.
metadata.notes: Preached at Grace Church, NYC. Notable for its engagement with 1990s cultural debates on multiculturalism and its use of humor/parables.

phase_1_concrete_experience.analysis: The sermon is grounded in specific, recognizable human encounters. It avoids abstract 'everyman' scenarios in favor of vivid, localized experiences in New York City. The preacher uses personal vulnerability (the crisis in his family) and specific characters (William on Fourth Avenue) to anchor the message in the hearer's world. The emotional connection is established through the contrast between 'proselytizing' (bad news) and 'evangelizing' (good news), which resonates with the hearer's social anxieties.
quotes: A few days ago... I heard an agnostic friend refer to the activity of the Christian church as 'proselytizing.'

William appears not to have had a bath for a very long time... His greatest sin is that he sleeps all day and preaches from the Bible at the top of his lungs all night right underneath my bedroom window.
strengths: Strong use of 'slices of life' that are geographically and socially specific.
Effective use of humor and personal anecdotes to lower the hearer's defenses.
improvement_points: The identification with biblical characters is minimal; the focus is almost entirely on contemporary characters.
The 'hook' is effective but could more explicitly connect the Trinity to the initial feeling of 'blood rising' at the start.
phase_1_concrete_experience.homiletical_manifestations: Manifests through the 'William' parable, the Billy Graham rally description, and the personal anecdote about the agnostic friend.

phase_2_reflective_observation.analysis: The sermon excels at analyzing the cultural condition of the 1990s, specifically the tension between multiculturalism and Christian testimony. It pauses to ask 'why' Christianity is viewed with suspicion and explores the problem of social fragmentation. It offers a cultural critique of the 'ruling class' and the 'media industry,' inviting the hearer to look at their environment through a different lens. However, it moves somewhat quickly from the problem of 'dirt' to the theological solution without a deep psychological exploration of why we fear 'the unwashed.'
quotes: We live in a strange time when, on the one hand, religious tolerance is prized, but on the other hand, actual Christian faith is regarded by the cultural tsars with suspicion.
There is an increasing fragmentation of American society into ethnic and political-interest groups.
strengths: Sharp cultural analysis of the 'multicultural logjam.'
Honest exploration of the 'problem' of religion versus the gospel.
improvement_points: Could spend more time on the internal 'Reflective Observation' of the hearer's own prejudices.
The transition from cultural fragmentation to the Trinity is logical but could be more existentially reflective.
phase_2_reflective_observation.homiletical_manifestations: Manifests as cultural critique, sociological observation (Schlesinger/Myrdal), and the exploration of the 'proselytizing' vs 'evangelizing' tension.

phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.analysis: The theological exposition of the Trinity is present but relatively brief. The preacher defines the Trinity as an 'event' and a 'relationship' rather than a dogmatic formula. While this makes it accessible, the exegesis of Matthew 28:18-20 is light; the text serves more as a springboard for the theme of mission than a subject of deep grammatical or historical study. The 'big idea'—that the Trinity is the wellspring of a new humanity—is clear and logically connected to the previous phases.
quotes: True relationships originate in God himself. That is what the Trinity signifies... God is in relationship within himself from before all time.
The doctrine of the Trinity is often criticized for being an abstraction. But it isn’t an abstraction. In the final analysis it is an event.
strengths: Translates a difficult dogma (Trinity) into a relational concept.
Clear logical connection between the nature of God and the nature of the Church.
improvement_points: Exegesis of the Great Commission is thin; more attention to the biblical text's structure would strengthen the conceptual base.
Theological depth is sacrificed for accessibility; more dogmatic 'meat' would satisfy the assimilating learner.
phase_3_abstract_conceptualization.homiletical_manifestations: Manifests in the definition of the Trinity as 'relationship' and the conceptual link between 'dirt' (sin) and 'cleansing' (atonement).

phase_4_active_experimentation.analysis: This is the weakest phase. While the sermon is highly 'missionary' in tone, it lacks specific, concrete action steps for the individual hearer in their daily life. It points to missionaries in Liberia and Nepal as examples, but the call to the congregation remains somewhat general: 'giving the good news away.' The 'how' of responding to the multicultural logjam in a personal capacity is left largely to the hearer's imagination, though the example of the preacher's own interaction with Jewish friends provides a subtle model.
quotes: It has been given to us precisely in order that we should give it away.
In him all races meet... In him there is news so good that we cannot possibly keep it to ourselves.
strengths: Provides a clear ethical call to be 'witnesses.'
Uses the example of church missionaries to demonstrate that action is possible.
improvement_points: Needs more 'Active Experimentation' handles: how does a hearer 'evangelize' without 'proselytizing' on Monday morning?
The application remains largely at the level of 'attitude' rather than 'action steps.'
phase_4_active_experimentation.homiletical_manifestations: Manifests as a general call to missionary identity and the invitation to the Eucharist as a site of reconciliation.

declarative_assimilating.preacher_role: The preacher acts as an Advocate for the 'Evangel' against the 'Religion' and 'Proselytism.'
declarative_assimilating.core_question_answered: What is the truth? The truth is that God is a relational Trinity who loves the ungodly.
declarative_assimilating.analysis: The sermon uses a deductive logic: if God is relational (Trinity), then the Gospel must be relational and inclusive.
quotes: The Christian gospel is good news for the godless, which reminds us to be more careful about stereotyping others.
improvement_points: Could provide more systematic theological grounding.

pragmatic_converging.preacher_role: The role of Guide/Coach is largely absent.
pragmatic_converging.core_question_answered: The question 'How does it work?' is answered only by pointing to the Eucharist and the example of missionaries.

narrative_accommodating.preacher_role: The preacher is a master Storyteller/Novelist.
narrative_accommodating.core_question_answered: What happens? A story of an agnostic friend, a homeless man, and a rally in Central Park.
narrative_accommodating.analysis: The sermon is driven by narrative movement and character sketches.
quotes: I was not prepared for what I saw there. It was by a long way the most truly multicultural group I have ever seen.
improvement_points: Ensure the stories always lead back to the biblical text.

visionary_diverging.preacher_role: The preacher acts as an Artist/Poet using the 'Pogo' metaphor.
visionary_diverging.core_question_answered: Why is this important? Because it is the only thing that can break the 'multicultural logjam.'
visionary_diverging.analysis: The use of 'D-I-R-T' and 'secret ingrediment' functions as a powerful visionary metaphor.
quotes: In him all threads are woven together.
improvement_points: Could expand the vision of the 'future Kingdom' more vividly.

descriptive_empirical.priestly_listening: The preacher is deeply tuned into the specific context of New York City and the cultural anxieties of 1993.
descriptive_empirical.analysis: Excellent identification of the 'multicultural logjam' and the specific social dynamics of the congregation's neighborhood.
quotes: many thoughtful people are worried about the way things are going. There is an increasing fragmentation of American society.
improvement_points: None, this is a strong point.

interpretive.wisdom_of_sage: Uses sociology (Myrdal) and history (Schlesinger) to interpret why society is fragmenting.
interpretive.analysis: The preacher looks beneath the surface of 'tolerance' to find 'hostility' toward faith.
quotes: actual Christian faith is regarded by the cultural tsars with suspicion, scorn, or outright hostility.
improvement_points: Could deepen the psychological interpretation of 'religion' as a defense mechanism.

normative.prophetic_discernment: The Trinity is presented as the norm for human community.
normative.analysis: The sermon brings the doctrine of the Trinity into dialogue with the problem of ethnic hatred.
quotes: The Trinity is the wellspring of a new humanity.
improvement_points: The dialogue with Scripture could be more robust.

pragmatic.servant_leadership: The sermon inspires but does not fully equip.
pragmatic.analysis: The response is primarily liturgical (Eucharist) and attitudinal rather than practical.
quotes: The preaching of the Word and the Sacrament of the Holy Eucharist today are... for all the unclean.
strengths: Focus on the Sacrament as a response.
improvement_points: Provide more 'servant leadership' handles for social action.

assimilating_style.analysis: The sermon provides a logical framework (Religion vs. Gospel) but may lack the systematic rigor some assimilators crave.
assimilating_style.risks: The theology of the Trinity is treated more as a 'story' than a 'system,' which might feel imprecise to this learner.

converging_style.analysis: The sermon is low on practical utility and problem-solving 'tips.'
converging_style.preferences_addressed: The relevance of the Gospel to the 'multicultural logjam.'
converging_style.risks: The hearer may leave inspired but unsure of what to 'do' on Monday.

accommodating_style.analysis: This is the primary style addressed. The sermon is intuitive, action-oriented (in its missionary examples), and feeling-based.
accommodating_style.preferences_addressed: The stories of William and the Billy Graham rally appeal to the 'doing and feeling' learner.
accommodating_style.risks: May lack enough doctrinal precision for some.

diverging_style.analysis: The sermon is highly imaginative and empathetic, using multiple perspectives (agnostic friend, Jewish friend, homeless man).
diverging_style.preferences_addressed: The 'Pogo' metaphor and the vision of a multiethnic gathering.
diverging_style.risks: The structure is somewhat loose, following a narrative flow rather than a rigid outline.

cycle_completeness.analysis: The sermon moves through the first three phases effectively but stalls at the fourth.
cycle_completeness.sequence_and_flow: Concrete Experience (Agnostic friend) -> Reflective Observation (Cultural critique) -> Abstract Conceptualization (Trinity as relationship) -> Active Experimentation (General call to witness).

balance_between_phases.analysis: The sermon is heavily weighted toward the 'Diverging' quadrant (Experience + Reflection).
balance_between_phases.consequences: Hearers will feel understood and inspired but may lack a sense of agency or direction.

homiletic_window_movement.analysis: The sermon moves from Narrative (opening story) to Visionary (the Pogo metaphor) to Declarative (Trinity) and ends with a brief Pragmatic (Sacrament).
homiletic_window_movement.effectiveness: The movement is smooth and keeps the hearer engaged, but the 'Pragmatic' landing is soft.

holistic_learning.analysis: Addresses the Heart (Experience) and Eyes (Observation) very well. The Head (Conceptualization) is addressed adequately. The Hands (Experimentation) are the least engaged.

overall_picture.summary: This sermon is a strong example of narrative-visionary preaching that deeply engages the hearer's context and emotions. It effectively deconstructs the 'religion' vs. 'gospel' dichotomy through vivid storytelling and sharp cultural analysis. However, it falls short of a complete Kolb cycle due to a lack of concrete, practical application (Active Experimentation). The theological treatment of the Trinity is accessible and relational but lacks the exegetical depth that would satisfy a more intellectually-oriented (Assimilating) learner. It is highly effective at creating a 'Visionary' sense of the Church's identity in a multicultural world, but it leaves the 'Pragmatic' implementation of that identity largely to the hearer's intuition.
strengths_top_5: Vivid, localized storytelling (William on Fourth Avenue).
Sharp and relevant cultural analysis of 1990s multiculturalism.
Effective use of humor and metaphor (Pogo's D-I-R-T) to convey theological truths.
Strong emotional resonance and personal vulnerability.
Clear and accessible translation of the Trinity into relational terms.
improvement_points_top_5: Strengthen Active Experimentation by providing 2-3 concrete ways to 'evangelize' in daily life.
Deepen the exegesis of Matthew 28:18-20 to provide a firmer biblical foundation.
Balance the narrative focus with more systematic theological 'meat' for the Assimilating learner.
Bridge the gap between the 'missionaries in Liberia' and the 'person in the pew' more effectively.
Develop the 'Reflective Observation' phase to include more self-examination for the hearer.
excluded_learning_styles: Converging learners (who need practical utility) and to a lesser extent Assimilating learners (who need systematic depth).
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Incorporate a 'How-To' section or a 'Pragmatic' handle in the final third of the sermon.
Spend more time in the biblical text itself (Exegesis) to ground the 'Big Idea' more firmly.
Use a 'Declarative' structure for at least one major point to satisfy logical learners.
overall_picture.conclusion: The sermon is an effective piece of communication that succeeds in making a complex doctrine (the Trinity) relevant to a specific cultural moment. Its strength lies in its 'Priestly listening' to the city and its 'Prophetic' vision of a reconciled community. From a Kolb perspective, it is a 'Diverging' sermon that excels at feeling and watching but hesitates at doing. To move from a 6.5 to an 8, the preacher would need to provide more concrete handles for active experimentation and a more robust exegetical framework for the abstract conceptualization. It remains a strong model for how to engage a secularized, multicultural audience without compromising the central claims of the Gospel.
